title: Sly Cooper's Cane Head
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I was asked by a friend to help him with a prop of Sly Cooper's cane. Here is a printable head for his cane, modelled in Fusion 360. The model is approximately 36cm tall when printed at 100% scale. Additionally, if you want to mount this on a dowel to create an actual cane, the bottom has a diameter of 1 1/4" (at 100% scale), so use that size dowel.

Reference image for modelling sourced from http://slycooper.wikia.com/wiki/File:Slycane.png
(included in the model images)

The model prints in 3 pieces. Print in orientations given, with pieces 1 and 3 upright and piece two upside down. I've included two versions of the parts 1 & 2 each with a different location of the division between them. Part 3 is the same for both versions. The first version is what I printed and what is shown in the images. The cut is in line wit the tip of the downward point. The largest piece is ~218mm tall, which the Tinkerine Ditto+ printer I used could accommodate. For smaller printers, use version two. It has the cut placed at the midpoint between the bottom of part 1 and the bottom of part 3. Parts one and two are both ~158mm tall in this version. If you still can't accommodate this size, you will have to make different divisions. A full, uncut version of the model has been included for this purpose.

I used white PLA, which my friend will most likely spray paint.
Metal fill material or acetone-smoothed and painted ABS would suit this model well.

Printer Brand:

Tinkertine Studio

Printer:

Ditto +

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%
I connected the 3 parts with superglue. Some sanding of the connecting surfaces helps the superglue bond the parts in my experience.

I modelled from an image, so I had to guess at the overall size. If you mean 1:1 scale relative to the real thing, well, the real thing is in a video game! I don't know exactly how large it should be. If you mean relative to my original model size (that's ~36cm vertically top to bottom), that's fine. Please clarify those details of your inquiry, and I'll do my best to help. One other thing, out of curiosity, what would you like the archive for?

title: Raspberry Pi Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple Raspberry Pi slot holder.

I wanted a compact, simple and convenient way of mounting my Pi to my monitor, which also allowed me to easily remove it if need be.

This design uses one of four available (VESA) screw holes in the back of your monitor/screen (I used an M4 x 12 Screw). Screw it to your monitor/screen and simply slide your Pi into the slots. Your are still able to access all ports (GPIO, HDMI, power and SD card) whilst it is inserted.

I have only tested this with my Raspberry Pi Model B, other Pi's may differ.

Enjoy :)

title: Hybrid direct flex optimized extruder with 8x12x3.5 bearing

description.text:
This is the extruder I designed specificaly as a replacement of wade geared extruder of prusa i3 (mk1/mk2).

This one is easily printable (there are only 2 parts requiring printing in ABS). The rest can be printed with PLA/PETG.

It uses one of the these 8x12x3.5 bearings instead of the big ones.

Because of how the motor is placed, there is minimal force (twisting momentum) on steel rods.
Model is split into parts that can be printed without supports.

title: Case for Anet A8 mainboard and 2 mosfet boards

description.text:
This is intended to be relatively compact enclosure for the Anet A8 mainboard and 2 of the commonly available mosfet boards with heatsinks.

I've now uploaded plain versions of the case and lid to make any remixes people may wish to make much easier.

I will most likely never print this model as I've been printing inside an enclosure since designing it.

Additions:

User Cu3ball decided to make a cover for their cables and make use of this as an external box for the boards. You can see the cover they designed to hide the cables here - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2437476

Tweaks - 15/09/2017

  • added separate files for the board mounting posts for the Anet board and for the mosfet boards in case people wish to use them in their designs.

Tweaks - 28/06/2017

  • Case_Design_Lid_4 - removed mounting holes for second 40mm fan and added a large hole to cut down on material use, reduce restriction of airflow and provide access to run the fan power cable.
  • Fan_Cover_Lid_4 - Changed size of hexagonal holes to be consistent with the lid and case, added routing channels for power/signal cable.

Update - 28/06/2017

  • Added another lid variant. This includes repositioned holes for the new 80mm fan cover. The STL for this is "Case_Design_Lid_4"
  • Added an optional 80mm fan cover for use with "Case_Design_Lid_4". File name is "Fan_Cover_Lid_4".
  • The lid fit on the case is unchanged but the fan cover should be considered untested. The pegs to connect to the fan in particular could prove to be fragile or too thin to print. It does look like it's sufficiently wide to print in thetest slicing I have done in S3D.

Update - 25/06/2017 -

  • Added a variant of the box lid which includes holes to mount an 80mm fan and/or a Raspberry Pi 3 on the exterior of the lid. If you want this version download Case_Design_Lid_3.stl. All of the features of Lid_2 remain in this design.

Tweak - 25/06/2017 -

  • Minor adjustment to honeycomb spacing. Slicing software was showing a small gap when printing with two perimeter shells. Please ensure that you have a relatively low minimum infill distance to get a better surface strength and finish.

Updates - 25/06/2017 -

  • Conversion of honeycomb holes to a distance of 0.8mm apart. I hope this will allow for a cleaner print of the honeycomb on a 0.4mm nozzle.
  • Raised exit holes in the sides to be in line with the top of a PCB!
  • Repositioned mainboard position to increase distance from X carriage and mount board closer to edge of case. Intent is to have motherboard line up with the pair of square holes for access to USB and microSD ports.
  • Removal of one hole in the top side to replace with the square holes mentioned above.
  • Removal of diamond shaped holes in sides.
  • Current versions are now 4 for case and 2 for lid.

Updates - 17/04/2017 -

  • Changed holes for A8 board to through holes to allow mounting to the frame
  • Corrected positions of mount points for main board
  • Moved main board mounting point closer to edge of case to better suit mounting on the printer.
  • Decreased size of ventilation holes to make printing of the main case more straight forward.
  • Added a cut out of the two mounting holes closest to the x-axis to allow people to test for fit before deciding to print the whole object.

The mosfet positions are adjacent to the side of the board rather than the bottom or top to (hopefully) assist with cable routing. The case lid is designed to be used with countersunk head screws (M3 screws for the sides of the case). Positions are included to attach a 40mm fan inside the enclosure above the mainboard. I intend to make a bracket for the second 40mm fan position to allow a fan to be mounted outside of the enclosure to ventilate the mosfet boards. Currently there is not enough vertical clearance inside the case above the mosfet board heatsinks (hence the need for the bracket). I plan to add some holes in the bottom of the case between the board mounting points to allow thin cable ties to be used to manage cables inside the enclosure. There are small pieces of support in the larger openings which are intended to be cut away after printing.

description.text:
So, maybe you found stumbled across one of the puzzle cubes I designed. (If you haven't, find them here! http://www.thingiverse.com/Wooden_Fish/collections/puzzle-cubes) Maybe you printed one out (and hopefully posted a make!). Maybe you were even able to solve and assemble it. Then what?

Enter Puzzle Cube Holder!

Just print it out and gently place your cube into it. It acts as a great display stand, and also helps to hold your cube together and out of harm's reach.

Printer:

Polar 3d

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Run through meshmixer to generate optimal print orientation and needed supports. You may want to scale up a couple per cent when slicing to assure your cube fits well.

Step 1

Remove the supports.

Step 2

Sand to achieve a flat, level bottom.

Step 3

Print out one of our puzzle cubes, solve, and proudly display!

As I've already mentioned, I have begun designing a collection of polycube packing problem puzzles. These include various popular puzzles I've found searching the web, as well as some generated by programs.

They range in skill level: some have hundreds of solutions and require only minutes, others have a single unique solution that takes hours to find.

Check out the collection, find a cube, and have fun solving!

http://www.thingiverse.com/Wooden_Fish/collections/puzzle-cubes

Nice looking Stearman style biplane. Prop spins and the main gear tires roll. This is a static display or kids toy, it will not fly. Style cues taken from the stearman and other period biplanes but it isn't intended to be a scale model of any of them.

Printer:

Hictop Prusa clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.06 on smalls .1 on everything else

Infill:

25 to 50%

Notes:

Fuselage length is 184mm. Top wing length is 176mm. The bottom wing prints in two halves that are then slid into the slot in the fuselage, this is a near perfect fit as printed on my printer. Print doubles on the struts and tires. Print all small parts including the engine at higher resolution for best results. Use 50% infill on the landing gear to make sure they are sturdy enough. The engine, prop, and prop retainer can be printed separately so the prop will spin, but it may give problems so a static version combining the pieces is included. An epoxy or other suitable adhesive is necessary to attach the landing gear and wing struts. The tires are held on with the hub cap which is a light press fit, no adhesive needed. The tail wheel prints with the fuselage but will probably break off when removing the supports so there is a separate tail wheel included in the stl's.
The holes for the struts and landing gear will need to be enlarged to accept these pieces, the printed holes are for reference only.
On the cabane struts I needed to align the diagonal brace on an axis and increase the scale for that axis by a factor of .1 for the cabanes to line up with the printed holes.

title: Lasercut 28mm SciFi Battle Computer - Lasercut 3mm MDF
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Your sensor or comms array is virtually useless with a way to process and display the data... To that end I present BattleComp Mk I. Voila! I recommend a slower speed (50) to etch the finer raster details, not more power. Now your battle objective marker just became real Boss! The accompanying Comms/Sensor can be found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2130136 - Includes two different base configurations. Would love to see how it turns out on acrylic?

I designed this as additional space filler for my lasercut projects. Produces one Battlecomp per sheet with a minimum 0.5" safety margin around edge of the frame. You can fit around a dozen on one 3mm MDF cut from 12" x 9" (Arch A sheet size), which uses only 1/4 of the bed on an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

title: Anet A8 Raspberry Pi Cam Holder

description.text:
I modified the screwless raspi cam mount by DanielBull to be mountable (with one screw) on the Anet A8. I also modified the cam case that fits the M12 raspi cam hack. Further I modified the back cover, because the original design scraped off some SMD parts of the cam. I only tested this design for the original Rev1.3 raspbbery pi cam. If you want to use it with another cam module, check the differences of the dimensions before you print this thing.

You need following parts for vanilla raspberry camera:

  • camera_holder_bracket_for_anet_a8.stl
  • camera_mount_front_by_DanielBull.stl
  • camera_mount_back_more_space.stl
  • camera_mount_hinge_by_DanielBull.stl

You need following parts for raspberry camera with M12 hack:

  • camera_holder_bracket_for_anet_a8.stl
  • camera_mount_front_m12.stl
  • camera_mount_back_more_space.stl
  • camera_mount_hinge_by_DanielBull.stl

You can mount the holder on each of the 2 outer holes on the back of the printer:

  • top left hole for the Anet A8 Board (picture). The M3 screw should be 4mm longer
  • left hole of the bottom left hole of the Anet A8 board. You need a M3x16+mm screw + M3 nut and a washer (optional)
  • same on the opposite side, where the power supply is mounted.

You can also use this screwless mount for the Anet A8 by OlliMakes instead of camera_holder_bracket_for_anet_a8.stl:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2474665

Depends on how far away your raspberry pi is from the camera, you may need a longer ribbon cable: https://goo.gl/8y9xqR
For the M12 hack, I used the lens + lens mount + lens cover from this arduino module: https://goo.gl/hfU63k

How to support me?

Do you like my things and do you want to support me? You can use these links if you want to buy something. This helps me doing more things. Thanks!

Banggood: https://goo.gl/ZXgx3A
Gearbest: https://goo.gl/FfE59f
Aliexpress: https://goo.gl/bQLi15

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

0.24

20%

Website

https://mightynozzle.com

title: Knitting Loom (150mm diameter, 26 pegs)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Knitting looms you can buy work great, but my mom wanted something that was between the smallest and second to smallest and had higher density of pegs. This is my attempt at it with OpenSCAD.

The scad file (attached) has modules to make it easy to render specific models for STL export:

  • all: hoop, side peg, and all main pegs
  • hoop: just the hoop
  • main_peg: one main peg
  • main_pegs: all needed main pegs (based on peg_count variable)
  • side_peg: the one side peg
  • test: one main peg, one side peg, and a slice of the hoop with 2 main peg holes and side peg hole

STL for the main modules have been attached, prefixed with string "loom_" obviously: hoop, main_peg, side_peg, and test.

Note the design is meant to make it easy to change all dimensions. Next sub-project may be to figure out how to make it a customizable object.

I'm super impressed by how well this turned out! If I had to adjust it I would:
1) make the radius a tiny bit larger.
2) increase height of main pegs by 3mm.
3) decrease height of side peg by 1mm.

I'll hold off on adjustments until it's given a real test: make a hat!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.22mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Print with brim for pegs:

  • 1x loom_hoop
  • 1x loom_side_peg
  • 26x loom_main_peg

I printed the 26 main pegs and one side peg at one time in ABS. They turned out amazing. I have problems printing the hoop in ABS so am going with PLA. So far so good, will post the final print when it's assembled.

Cleanup

If you printed pegs with brim, you'll need to clean up the peg heads.
For the hoop should only need to cleanup blemishes on outside (sand paper) and maybe the side peg hole. I just trimmed back the very outside of that hole and the side peg went right in.

Assembly

Can push pegs in by hand or lightly tap in with a mallet. I had a wooden mallet I used to gently tap them in after aligning each one. Very easy.

comments.text: Have gotten feedback on using this and will have to smooth the pegs. Maybe consider printing them on their side to allow the hook to side easily.

Three variations on the Windsor chair in 1:24 scale: low back, fan back and sack back. There are designed to be built without support. Delicate but surprisingly sturdy. Shown with a dime for scale. There's a short time-lapse here: http://flic.kr/p/bQpBB8

I'm running skeinforge 47 on a Replicator and needed to make the following adjustments to the stock profile:
Under Dimension, set "Extra Restart Distance" to 0
I print these in pairs, to give the print cooling time without waisting time. I prefer printing them in a line along the y axis instead of side by side to keep my second extruder from interfering.
35mm/s works well for me, 40mm/s travel
These are designed for printing at .25mm layer height. The bridges are carefully designed in and I can't guarantee this will print at other slicing heights.
*The file includes small discs under each chair leg. A raft is unnecessary.

comments.text:
I'm sure there is a reason for this but on your 1:24 scale if I use 1"=1.06mm instead of 1mm it works out better for 12 inches to =12.7mm ect, ect.
Am I missing something? Can I just use 1.06 as a multiplier without using the equation?
comments.author: Robaktime

comments.text: The values on my scale charts are rounded off. I don't use 1" as a multiplier exactly, it's just how I think about values less than 1' while I'm modeling.  I tend to use the whole chart - if I need something 10', grab that value and use it, rather than multiplying 1.06 by the number of inches (120) - but if a multiplier feels right to you - go for it.  I usually don't model out to two decimal points, unless I'm planning for layer width or thread width.

comments.text: how is it able to print the stretchers and top rails without drooping? these are awesome and great for demonstrating the abilities of the machine
comments.author: GaryJSmith

comments.text: 3D printers can do bridges pretty easily - there are lots of bridge test objects on thingiverse that span much longer distances.  It's about balancing temperature and speed to get a line that doesn't droop (or does, if that's what you're after.)  You need to design your object to follow two rules: 1. You can print in mid-air, but it needs to start and end on something in order to work.  2. Only bridge in one direction at a time.  If you look carefully at the STL or time-lapse, you'll notice the front to back stretchers are printed first.  On the next layer, the middle stretcher is added.  Same idea for the bridging that starts the seat of the chair. Side to side is accomplished in one layer, front to back in the next.
comments.author: GaryJSmith

description.text:
I had a look for existing fume extractors for the PC case fan I had lying around but didn't find one that fit exactly what I wanted with the supplies I had on hand. So I designed this in an afternoon.

This is a snap-fit case and requires no screws or gluing. The unit is powered by 3x 18650 batteries (can be found from old/dead laptop batteries) and thus is completely wireless which is great for keeping the workbench free of tangles. It also makes it portable and great for in situ jobs in tight spaces.

Bill of materials (non-printed):
80x80x20mm fan (capable of running at 12v)
80x80x9mm piece of carbon filter (optional but recommended)
20x15mm rectangle rocker switch
3x 3,7v 18650 battery cell (wired in series for 11.1v nominal)
wire (I used salvaged copper wire from scrap power cables)
tape (optional but makes assembly easier)

Printer:

Rigidbot Regular

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

2.5

Infill:

15

Notes:

The first test print I did was at 15% infill and it actually worked fine (apart from the delamination and brittleness I get from my poor quality ABS spool). My fan guard actually stuck to the bed so hard it snapped off when I removed the rest of the part. This shouldn't happen with regular ABS or PLA but I might need to make that part thicker.

title: Ventricular system of the Brain / Ventricles of the Brain with stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For a start, let's understand in short, what the ventricular system is?
The ventricular system is a set of four interconnected cavities called ventricles (see diagram) inside the brain, where the cerebro-spinal fluid (CSF) is produced. The ventricular system is continuous with the central canal of the spinal cord, from the fourth ventricle (see diagram) allowing for the flow of CSF to circulate.

I have also uploaded a quirky diagram that shows what the different parts are.
You can read more about this unique and clinically significant anatomical part on this informative page.

After fusing, sharpening and analyzing the boundaries & structure of the extracted ventricles from the repository, I have also modeled a stand for holding upright the ventricular system so you can showcase it where you desire. This can be printed as an educational model to teach students about how the ventricular volumes are connected.

This unique addition to Thingiverse has been made possible because of medical data sets available online that have further been post-processed using mesh manipulation tools.

Thank You!

Diagram Image Source
Model Repository Source

Notes:
Model Update v1.2 [07/28/2017] Thingiverse user Debra Summers noticed separate shells on the model while slicing. The error is fixed and a revised and renamed model has been updated in the files section.('Ventricles_updated')

Introduction: The Ventricular System Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) circulates throughout and around the central nervous system (CNS). In the brain, CSF is produced in special structures to perfuse through the nervous tissue of the CNS and is continuous with the interstitial fluid. Specifically, CSF circulates to remove metabolic wastes from the interstitial fluids of nervous tissues and return them to the blood stream. The ventricles are the open spaces within the brain where CSF circulates. In some of these spaces, CSF is produced by filtering of the blood that is performed by a specialized membrane known as a choroid plexus. The CSF circulates through all of the ventricles to eventually emerge into the subarachnoid space where it will be reabsorbed into the blood. The two ventricles are in the left and right sides, and were at one time referred to as the first and second ventricles. The interventricular foramina connect the frontal region of the lateral ventricles with the third ventricle. All the four ventricles have developed from the original hollow space within the neural tube, the central canal. The first two are named the lateral ventricles and are deep within the cerebrum. lateral ventricles are C-shaped as they assume the shape of the Telencephalon as it grows into the cranial cavity during neural development. These lateral ventricles are connected to the third ventricle by two openings called the interventricular foramina/opening. The third ventricle is the space between the left and right sides of the diencephalon, which opens into the cerebral aqueduct that passes through the midbrain. The cerebral aqueduct is also called as the Aqueduct of Sylvius. The aqueduct opens into the fourth ventricle, which is the space between the cerebellum and the pons and upper medulla. Glossary:
Telencephalon - The telencephalon is the embryonic structure from which the cerebrum develops prenatally. Neural tube - The primordium of the brain and spinal cord; derived from the neural ectoderm, the most superficial of the three embryonic germ layers; gives rise to the nervous system and epidermis. Choroid Plexus - Specialized structures containing ependymal cells lining blood capillaries that filter blood to produce CSF in the four ventricles of the brain. Diagrammatic representation of The Ventricular System

description.text:
I wanted to create a pair of upper Lack table enclosure brackets that would allow the use of cut glass without having to drill it.The brackets are designed to be screwed on with #6 wood screws and glued to a plain sheet of glass. The glass can then can be swung upward allowing removal in this position.

The hinges are designed so as to allow the glass to be slid out of the brackets for complete removal. The idea is if you just need to reach inside you can raise the sides up and if you're doing more extensive work, raise the glass to 90 degrees and then draw it forward to remove it entirely.

Three formats of glass mount. 2 mil and 3 mil (3 mil file named "3.2mm".) and one sided epoxy on for minimal clearance.

Sliced in Cura PLA Medium, 1.2mm top/bottom/wall, 10% fill on glass piece, 30% fill on cabinet piece, no supports.

Note: Lightly sand or file off any printing anomalies/deformations if they occur particularly at edges where the parts interconnect. When deformations are removed these pieces operate together smoothly and in close tolerance. I remained tight on tolerances since I wanted to limit the glass rattling while the printer was operating so this extra step may be necessary depending on your print quality.

comments.text: Could you possibly add some pictures of it in use or a video showing how it all comes together? I'm a little bit confused as to how it works but I'm making an enclosure and want to have a clear glass door on the front that opens without having to drill any holes for hinges and this appears to work without having to drill and holes in the glass. Thanks, Michael.

45, 55, 60, and 65 degree angles available. You will need to print both a right and left leg.

Designed from scratch based on andyleer's 45 degree stand.

description.text:
A simple GoPro session mount with space to hold it in place with a battery strap. Screws on over the top of the front bit. Sits at a 30deg angle.

Will fit battery straps 20mm x 1.5mm --- you'll need to squeeze it in but it'll get there.

This will most likely make your GoPro the most forward thing in the craft so I'd highly recommend a lens protector or case. I made one that you might want to try out.

It also will, more likely than not, hurl your GoPro forward in the event of a crash. It feels pretty solid with the battery strap down tight, but perhaps you could add some velcro or something else to keep it right in there. I wasn't too keen on some of the other full case designs, even though they'd be way stronger.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed with 0.2mm shell thickness, otherwise the screw part would tear itself off. Designed for the threaded rod that comes with the Anet A8 printer and two 688ZZ bearings. But any bearing that is 16mm in diameter should fit in theory right?

description.text: I found that the spool holder on my A8 was lacking.... I was always worried that the filament would snap as the printer pulled on it. Seeing that I consistently get filament from the same supplier, and the spools always have the same bore diameter, I decided to just design this one part, that is sort of fixed as to the diameter of the spool. I had some 688ZZ bearings lying around, and decided to finally get around to making this. I am aware that it isn't extremely economical. So any suggestions on how to improve it would be much appreciated. (I am using it in conjunction with this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1743397)

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

35%

Notes:

I printed with 0.2mm shell thickness, otherwise the screw part would tear itself off. Designed for the threaded rod that comes with the Anet A8 printer and two 688ZZ bearings. But any bearing that is 16mm in diameter should fit in theory right?

this was a quick (30min) design of a cap for a coffee perkolator.
the original was just a metal cap, and the instructions referenced a see-thru cap for timing how long to let the coffee perk, needless to say, that won't be as easy with an all-metal cap.

the cap is 4" round for the inner ring.

this is designed to print with transparent ABS, or another transparent high temp plastic.

and since this is for a food type item, make sure to thoroughly clean your item and make sure you know where your filament and extruder have been.

ultimately, it's up to you to make sure you know how to make your printer semi-food safe.

i highly recommend if you print in ABS, to do a good amount of vapor smoothing, to get rid of ridges that particles and un-wanted stuff can get stuck in-between.

Make a cool key chain for yourself! If you have some time to spare, try to color it. It will look so much better. I used a base coat of white primer and acrylic paint on top. Finished with clear satin coat. Models for the other 3 pairs are also uploaded with different names. Just search for it. Enjoy!

This is a small pry bar for getting stubborn parts off the print bed. The hope is that the rounded fulcrum will ding my bed less than a sharp angled one would. Works best on parts with some kind of chamfer or lip at the bottom.

I have a PEI bed, and print a lot of wide flat parts that can be a pain to get off. To avoid that first "sharp" layer from hotter/low printed first layers, I usually add a chamfer to the base of my designs. This pry bar gets under that chamfer and helps pop prints off.

Printed in PETG, 40% infill. I used 3 perimeter layers for extra strength in the tip. Printing with a smaller extrusion width will give you a sharper tip.

The QU-BD OneUp and TwoUp come with a bunch of fragile little washers that you stack up to form a guard around a bearing. One of mine broke, and I decided that I'd print a replacement.  
So, attached is the STL of an bearing guard for the QU-BD OneUp and TwoUp, which can be used in three places in the assembly (two pairs on the Y axis, one pair on the X axis) using a guard instead of each pair of washers.

description.text: This is a quadcopter FPV 250 build, I have took much time on it,I will share my quadcopter build experiences to you. Before build a quadcopter, you’d better know some quadcopter knowledge and prepare the materials of quadcopter. I will list my quadcopter 250 materials and the step of build this quad.

Preparing Quadcopter FPV 250 Materials

HobbyKing/Diatone 250mm FPV "Long" frame (FPV250L)
HobbyKing KK2.1.5 Mini flight control,
Emax MT2204 Motor/Prop/ESC set with the TATTU 30A BLHeli_S ESC
Tattu 1300mah 4S lipo battery(Tattu is the best recommend quad battery)
Matek mini PDB (I need the BEC power anyway so may as well do it neat)
Assorted cabling bits to link the yet-to-be-bought receiver to the flight controller
Programmer to suit the KK2.1.5 so I can flash on the newest firmware etc
XT60 adapter to get my old battery charger (LiPo friendly) up-to-date and back to work.

Tattu 1300mAh 4s 75C lipo The Frame Kit

I used AUD7.66 for the frame and to be honest it's good enough to warrant that price but not much more. See by the time you assemble it and realise that every screw is made from really nasty metal (although they are light) and a few mm too short to do the job well it doesn't take a genius to see another AUD5-10 being spent beefing up the hardware. I, however, will persist with using the provided hardware for a bit.

There is only 3-4mm of screw engagement into the posts of the upper/lower deck. The camera mount fits securely and seems to allow some flexibility for camera choice. The decks mount to the plastic "X" at four points with the same lousy too short screws. The Motor Set

The motors mounted up to the frame arms perfectly, this time the screws included in the EMAX kit were perfect, long enough to fully engage into the motor base but not jam the motor.  Two sets come in the kit, long and short.  I used the long - the short are probably perfect on Carbon arms.
It was when I mount the props I struck the snag.  Literally.
The 6" 6045s don't clear the body of the frame.  5" props are likely to "just" clear so I guess my next purchase of props will be a mix of lengths!  
In the mean time I switched the decks to the under-slung location which also looks pretty cool.  The other advantage is much easier access to the flight controller this way.  

The Motor Set (EMAX MT2204/6045 Props) Next Bits (like Wiring)

The whole reason for starting the assembly was to work out positioning and wiring of most of the elements. My ESCs will lay neatly on the arms and I’ll direct solder them to the motors. This will be super neat looking. On the other end of the ESC I’ll shorten and run each control pair to the flight controller, each length customised to suit.
With the underslung deck I can mount my battery to the bottom deck (inside the frame) with velcro strapping. I’m considering mounting the Matek PDB/UBEC underslung vaguely in the centre of the frame. This keeps the power wiring routed well away from of there signal wiring.
The flight controller will need to mounted slightly rear-of-centre so that the buttons for setup are accessible, and that tiny little screen angled to make it more visible.

Then as per my other thread I started to think about propellers.

Result: Another box of bits ordered from Hobbyking (Mixed 5″ Props mainly)

Then I thought about my BLHeli EMAX ESCs and figured having the ability to update/flash them could be good.

Result: Arduino Nano ordered via Banggood,

Bought a bunch of Props during the week, just some random cheap HobbyKing (AUD0.32 a pair) 5045’s and some Diatone triple 5040’s – now have 4 complete sets of props to break in my maiden flight. .

Also grabbed some cheap micro-servos for the cheap and nasty gimbal (AUD4.95 gimbal, sub AUD4 servos)

Remembered (this time) to get a battery strap or two as well.

Wiring Step1

I stripped off the heat shrink so I could de-solder the signal wires - only 2 as my ESCs are Opto.  By customising their length at this end I don't need to play with new connectors at the F/C end.  
I'm leaving the motor leads long with their 2mm bullet connectors at least until I have worked out the motor rotation directions etc.  

Wiring Step 2

I mounted my Matek PDB to the underside of the "X" section.  I've used 3M Automotive DS Tape.  It's not going to fall off. 
In this pic you can see I've biased it rear wards and soldered two of the ESC power feeds on.  The ESC wires are trimmed to length and protected with heat shrink tube.
Here's the PDB with all four ESCs soldered.  The semi-central location did make wiring easy and I think overall it looks pretty tidy.

Wiring Step 3

On the upper side I've temporarily mounted the F/C on a foam block to let me get the wiring runs the way I wanted.  If it's not obvious yet I'm also mounting the ESCs on the underside of the arms (there's shallow recesses in the arm for this).
The F/C input from the RX will the routed on the other side of the F/C giving some balance.

Wiring Step 4:

Now that everything has a place I re-heatshrunk the ESCs, cable tied the wiring runs on the arms and generally tidied up.

The ESCs are DS taped into the recess, wiring held with cable ties at each end and then a loop of tape is used. 

Other Suff:

I've used Loctite on the lower deck screws and will do the upper screws in the next phase of assembly.  For the moment I've taken the Gimbal off the front.
I powered up the unit and rather satisfyingly got some beeps from the Warning buzzer, and a melody of sorts played on Motor - 2.  Not sure if thats normal.
The F/C could see the correct battery voltage.
Overall I'm really happy with my effort.

author: sunny1cnh

description.text:
this is a Team Associated RC10T2 from the mid 90's, one of my favorite old R/C vehicles.

this is the model that has helped me learn how to model in Inventor and now Fusion 360.
i started this model way back in 2010, and completed it in about a month.
i've now resurrected it to help me learn how to do things in Fusion 360, and it worked great for that purpose.

it's nearly fully rigged... the suspension on all 4 corners work and are limited in travel by the shocks, the steering works, but i think it could use some limiting for the outer hubs, to prevent some inversions that happen occasionally. what it is slightly missing, is contact sets to enable the gears inside the tranny and motor/main gear.

for those that want a nice big project to learn joints and assembly with in Fusion 360, i can upload a version that has no joints enabled, so you can try your hand at it.

most of this probably isn't printable, but you are more than welcome to try. hehe
i tried to make this as accurate and detailed as possible, even down to the ball bearings inside the tranny diff, but there are some errors. (i challenge you to find them! hehe)
technically, you probably could print the arms and rims, and maybe even some of the steering arms, but the rest is probably just too small, or is metal.

i hope by seeing this wonderful model, that you might be inspired to learn how to do some 3d modeling.

if you do manage to print parts of this, please take some pics and post an "I Made One" under this object, i would really love to see them!

Update 3-25-17: i now have every part uploaded in STL. hardcore puzzle mode file has been uploaded, check the render towards the end to see what the scattering looks like. you are in for a real challenge there! if you do decide to take a try at this puzzle challenge, please leave a comment about how you did!

i started by taking the physical item and removing each part and carefully measuring them, (best i could do, before i had good calipers w/ depth gauge) and then using those measurements to mack each individual part, which i then placed each one into an Inventor assembly, and began rigging it all up as i was building the parts.

fast forward to 2017, and i finally decide to install Fusion 360, since i got a new cheap printer (TronXY P802E), and needed to start doing some modeling again.
i was able to import all the files properly, but the Inventor rigging didn't transfer.
i guess that turned out to be a semi-good thing, since it helped me learn how joints and things worked in this new software.
i started rigging it all up in Fusion 360, and quickly learned that the joints were quite a bit different than what i was used to from Inventor, and had to re-think a bunch of things on how to put it all together.
i eventually figured out how most of the joints worked in Fusion 360, and was able to get what you see in the .F3D file.

as for the body, i couldn't measure it as good as the individual parts, so it suffered badly from my organic modeling skills. (read: none. lol)

description.text:
So i had a problem, i used an awesome spool holder that was mounted on my wall next to my printer, and everything worked. title: a bracket to attach your kinect to a standard tripod

description.text: This is a bracket to attach a kinect sensor to a tripod. I needed to make it for motion capture. I put the sensor on a piece of paper, traced round the base, photographed the paper with my phone, then imported the picture as an image plain in Maya. I edited a poly primitive to get the initial shape, then add brackets and 'pimped it up' a bit. The hole in the middle is 5mm diameter. this allows you to tap a thread on the inside to fit your camera (usually 1/4"-20 NC)

author: dropdeaddeek

title: Anti backlash Z isolator for 3D printers

description.text:
This is my design to avoid wobble on the hotend caused by a not straight z-rod.
This thing avoids both wobble and nut backlash by isolating the x and y movement of the z-rod. Of course you can solve all these problems by buying a very G$$D quality z-rod. :-) Z-isolator in action:
http://youtu.be/Ix8PHHisDuw
The entire systems is composed by 3 modifications and 1 optional improvement, more details on the images.

description.header: To assemble this z-isolator you'll need:
description.text:
• 2 printed z-isolator;
  • 4 M8 nuts;
  • 2 springs;

• Drill your x-ends to enable the x/y movement of the z rod;
  • Install some z-constraint at the z-rod top (e.g. thing:9864);
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9864
  • Install your new printed z-isolator right below your current x-ends;
  • Alternatively install your flexible z-couplers .

comments.text: Nice design! Just as a tip: I would recommend you to use a brass nut, same materials for nut and rod will wear out after some time!

comments.text:
Wow your lead screw looks like it has a TON of wobble in that video...is that a typical amount?
So, is the x axis now held to your isolator just by gravity? you could freely lift up the whole x axis assembly?
Does that add any lash or other issues?
looks like it works well, especially from the other comments, just wanted some more details.

comments.author: archy587

comments.text:
It depends on the screw you have. I got a very bad and cheap one :-)
Right, by gravity and it is very helpful for maintenance. I don't have to turn the screw to make it move up.
No issues were find on my setup, only improvements: the wobble disappeared.
If you are building something from scratch I suggest you to go by M5 screw. On my new setup I have M5 screw and M10 smooth rod, so even if M5 is not straight the M10 will hold all in place! ;-)
comments.author: archy587

comments.text:
As you can see in the video, the wobbling comes from your crappy z-couplers, not from bent rods.
The motor shafts axis and the axis of the threaded rod do not align correctly. This is why you have that bad wobbling.

Set 4 perimeters and 4 - 5 top/bottom solid layers it should be kids resistant.
The print could come out better, maybe different slicer settings or different slicer program.
Hexagon key holder.
Light Bumper (NinjaFlex) for https://github.com/LgHS/international-hackerspace-foosball

Have you ever had a print that messed up early on? So you canceled it and then had to remove what it had already printed that was 1, 2, or maybe 3 layers thick?  
You noticed how flexible it was? Even when printed in PLA? This got me thinking. In some cases you may want to design a thing where a certain part of it has a certain give to it, a certain flexibility.  
I know I have some stuff I want to do in this category. Instead of trying in a hit-or-miss fashion to get what I want, I created this Flexibility Test Gauge. It prints tines in .2mm thickness increments.  
Print it out using the type of plastic you want to use for the thing you are designing, and use the same shells and infill too (this way your thing that you are designing should have the desired flex that you want it to.  
This print I did on my Makerbot Replicator 2 took a little more than an hour (1 hour 6 minutes), medium rez (.2mm layer height), shells:2, infill: 25%.  I used True Orange PLA filament.  
The tines have the thickness# in millimeters embossed on them. For some reason the decimal point did not get rendered on the actual print. Rather than wrestle with that I just did a dot for each decimal with a Sharpy pen on the finished model.  
I took a silver metallic Sharpy and lightly colored the top of the raised lettering (I think it came out pretty cool)!  
Print and have fun imagining new and interesting designs!

Yet another OpenSCAD library to create helices.

There is plenty of libraries out there, but most of them are unpredictable. The height, width, angle, etc are not respected, making it very hard to create precise model.

This library is very precise, flexible and easy to use. It takes a 2D polygon and extrude it just like linear_extrude and rotate_extrude.

2018-02-24: Added a default value for the number of segments (precision) when $fn is not defined.

Using hull() to join polygons has some downsides:

  • Polygons needs to be extruded into 3D shape for hull to work properly.
  • Concave polygons are made convex.
  • Hull is overkill for what I'm doing, it takes too long to render.

The only way I can see to fix this without changing the API is to iterate through points of the polygon, and create the polyhedron manually. Unfortunately, this is not possible with the current version of OpenSCAD.

I could change the API and expect an array of points representing the polygon, but I don't like that idea. I want it to works like the other extrude functions.

A workaround for the concave issue is to create a convex polygon and extrude it with helix_extrude. Then create another polygon, extrude it with helix_extrude and create a difference between the two helices.

include <helix_extrude.scad>
helix_extrude()
    translate([10, 0, 0])
        circle(r=3);

I wanted a decent hand held gimbal but didn't want to shell out the bucks for something like an Osmo.
This is revision 2 of the hand held gimbal, a much better design. The battery cover is a tight fit, depending on your printer, some sanding might be necessary. It uses 10mm tube to mount the gimbal, I used some spare carbon fiber one from my drone. A 1000mah lipo fits nicely in the handle and is cover by the handle cover. I added a thumb joystick for gimbal control and the cover in screwed over it, link below. If you use the joystick, it needs removed from the casing it comes in and just the circuit board, thumbstick and wire leads are used. The joystick thumb cover has a 2mm post that holds the joystick circuit board secure in the handle.
I use a dys smart 3 axis gimbal, but this would work with any gimbal that uses a 60mm rail system. The top handle can be slid on the 10mm rails and adjust for best grip.
It also uses an on/off switch. I used a spare from my parts bin but the link below has one that would work.

https://www.amazon.com/powerdayHHG-JS-Joystick-controller-Controller-Stabilizer/dp/B01L6VG13Q/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1490350227&sr=8-1&keywords=gimbal+joystick

https://www.amazon.com/Square-Bezel-Momentary-Rocker-Switch/dp/B004GIJ05I/ref=sr_1_10?ie=UTF8&qid=1490413010&sr=8-10&keywords=square+on+off+switch

comments.text: I added a picture of the back of the gimbal, it's upside down but you should be able to decipher it.  The joystick I used had the wires were color coded so it wasn't to hard matching it up.  Also if you look closely at your gimbal, assuming you're using the same one I did, the pins are labeled.  More than that I can't tell you as I haven't had this in my possession for sometime.  Just remember that black and white banded wires are most likely pwoer and ground and the rest are for control, so just make sure they go in the signal pins.

This is a basic vertical stand to store your Wacom Bamboo and stylus while not in use. Drawn in Tinkercad, hence the visible dome segments.
It's a bit too small as the tolerances are not large enough to allow one-handed removal, so scale this up about 5-10%.
The stylus is also too close and will tend to interfere with the mouse pointer unless the tablet is flipped to face the other way.

My settings:
CocoonCreate / Wanhao Duplicator i3v2.
220 degrees
Layer height, and other settings don't really affect it, but dial in retraction settings to reduce cleanup time once printed.

author: sunkauyung

description.text:
The updated and final version!
M42 lens to Canon EOS body adapter. Made as a remix from three "things". Many thanks to the authors. Well, it will take a while until I will be able to test it. If there are courageous, please test it...

Adapter assure a flange distance of 45.5mm, needed by M42 lenses to focus to infinity (EOS flange distance is 44mm so, it adds 1.5mm), but, as I have zero experience with 3D printing, there is no dimensions tolerance. However, this is intended to be printed on Prusa i3 using Cura 3D software, where material is PLA and the profile is set to High Quality (0.06mm), infill %100.

Now, what I got from those three things:

  • from @SkyRzn I got the entire EOS bayonet, cut the extension tube and kept only 1.5mm from it; https://www.tinkercad.com/things/eZ0xn72o6Zj/
  • from @jeng28 I got the secure hole and the index hole of the EOS flange; https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0lSVNIOYrTU/
  • from @profhankd I got the first 6 millimeters of the M42 screw https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:132781 .

I should add that the EOS bayonet is procedurally generated in python language, resulting a script for OpenSCAD and it is a (very) tight fit to assure stability (good for metal body flange, but bad for composite body flange as in EOS SL1 body). The program was written by @SkyRzn.

Thank you guys for your work! And special thanks to the guy that tested the previous version and found out that the procedural M42 screw wasn't usable (see the comments).
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jI6Te3Pbb6Y

A big thank you to @Noserider that got this working with a slight change in dimensions. I will make the change in files as soon as he will answer my questions.

BTW, there are some goodies hidden inside the archive...

comments.text: Works great. To anyone who plans on printing this considers changing the dimensions before slicing for the X and Y axis from original 60.6mm to 60mm. I printed a couple of versions as the original was slightly large and the one with 60mm X and Y axis fits nicely.
comments.author: Noserider

comments.text: Thank you very much @Noserider, very much appreciated! Can you share your printer and your printer settings, please? Is this X,Y size change true for any printer? What software you used for slicing?
comments.author: Noserider

comments.author: kungpaogao

comments.text: Done! I replaced the M42 screw with the one indicated (and tested) by you! Thank you again!
comments.author: kungpaogao

comments.text: Wow, thanks so much! I'll try to test it soon :)
comments.author: funlw65

comments.text: Thank you very much for your feedback! The fins are designed by its author with the intent to have it tight, especially because there was no other way to lock it in place. This is good for a completely metallic body flange/bayonet, but bad if the bayonet is "composite", part metal, part plastic as is the case of Rebel SL1. Initially, I used that rear lenscap for the M42 screw but i opted for the procedural one... I will undo that mistake but I also don't have time in the near future. Do what you can and thank you again!

This Thing called Castle Twist was a two week project, planing, designing and constructing a game inspired by the Barbie World.

How to play - Each player gets four 10mm marbles and one catapult to play. The goal is to shoot four marbles into the small tower facing you. if you hit the big tower you must turn the bridge, all marbles roll down and the game restarts.

(Print all parts separate and plug them together to play. "Trichter and Turm klein" should be possible to print as one, but I didn't try it yet)

All files and photos
by Timoflury & Nicolaborrer BA Industrial Design ZHdK

CoreXY is a mechanism for building fast, compact XY motion stages. While it is not a CNC tool in of itself, the intention is that it might be incorporated into 3D printers, milling machines, etc. The design is described in greater detail at http://www.corexy.com . A video is at http://vimeo.com/40914530 .

comments.text:
I was implementing H-bot in Cartesio, but stopped
CoreXY is actually better, and I will implement CoreXY
In H-bot if you move 45 degrees only 1 motor is turning, and if the belt is not perfectly aligned and tensionedÂ  the opposite side of the gantry from the motor will start moving later, resulting in serious backlash
This will not happen with CoreXY
I will keep you updated
comments.author: jos

comments.text:
Â Edit: the same thing will happen for CoreXY
picture the reference mechanisme pic on your website.
Now if you move the toolholder from top left to bottom right in a 45 degree angle,
The "B" motor will be doing all the work resulting in the "A" side of the gantry to start moving ever so slightly later, resulting in backlash

comments.text: Indeed, CoreXY is functionally similar to the H configuration. If you look at the reference section on the website there's a few other interesting bits of information on the H mechanism. Because CoreXY has two belts instead of one I suspect it's bit stiffer than the equivalent H-bot. Of course you could use twice as thick a belt for the H config but that's not as readily available.

comments.text: I agree with your philosophy of keeping the moving mass low.  I have not been able to combine x and y motor movement with Marlin or Sprinter and still have jogging function.  If someone could do the firmware modification that allows us to combine axes, it would open up some great new possibilities.  How are you accomplishing the combined x and y movement?  Great work!
comments.author: dkennell

comments.text: I've modified the Marlin firmware to support CoreXY - it seems to work fine but I'm not sure what will happen at high speeds (I've run it successfully up to 100mm/s). Jogging works fine.
comments.author: dkennell

comments.text: thanks man. great work.
comments.author: frankie

comments.text: I'm not familiar with the workings of Marlin or Sprinter but a forward step in the X axis requires forward steps on both motors, while a forward step in Y requires a forward step on one motor and a reverse step on the other. If the firmware is written so that taking steps on each motor is broken out as separate functions it should be an easy modification. But in practice I don't know how easy it is to modify Marlin or Sprinter. I use my own control boards so the change was trivial.
comments.author: dkennell

comments.text: I'm using firmware that I wrote - it isn't as good as sprinter or others but I know how to modify it.

comments.text: were there any limitation to movements, as i am reading about it it comes to know that its only good for point to point movements,i havent seen any arc movements with this type of mechanics
comments.author: frankie

comments.text: All CNC machines that I know of operate on a grid defined by the resolution of their positioning system. Because of this arc movements are created by a series of very small point-to-point motions. CoreXY can move thru curves quite well.

title: Customizable storage/components drawer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A replacement storage/components box/drawer that you can customize.
Inspired by timfou's model : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2200136

Check or adjust the drawer parameters. you can add or remove dividers by editing the "DPos" vector.
Render the "Drawer", the "Handle" and the "Divider".
Print one of each (more dividers if needed) and assemble. You certainly will have to glue the sliders of the "Handle" in place.

All can be printed without supports, even if the bottom of the drawer might need some filing/sanding.

The source file is (heavily) commented...

Note: I still haven't printed this, but I cannot see why it would fail...

Printer:

CTC Bizer Dual

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

at least 30%

comments.text: This is a very nice improvement. I like the idea of printing the handle as a different piece so you don't need supports. Well done. Time for me to download and learn OpenSCAD!

comments.text: Thanks for your model... OpenSCAD is quite easy if you have some programming bases and understand that it's not a procedural language...

description.text:
I've seen similar designs on other masks to make them more comfortable I've only tried this for one night, and at this point and it made a huge difference !.  
Just make sure you clamp it on the free end of the strap so it can move and not dig into your head.  
Enjoy :).

comments.text: This device has done good things for me.  I had pretty much retired my SwiftFX headgear because it felt I was dragging it around by my nose.  (I went back to using the SwiftLX, which has a built-in head-clip.)  After printing this one nifty little piece, I've pulled the FX off of the shelf and am sleeping more comfortably than ever.

author: meson-01

title: K8200 / 3DRAG X-Axis GT2 Belt Modification
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE: I made a better X-axis idler pulley mounting - see here:http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:253357 This ist the first part of improvements i made on my K8200 from Velleman. The standard X Axis idler pulley achived by a ordinary bearing was removed and replaced by a toothed pulley. Additional i decide to change the T5 belt to a precise GT2 belt system.
By virtue of this modifications i had the need for a new device holder. I have two different version provided. One explicite for GT2 assembly, the other for any kind of pulley with variable mounting options.

Description for the GT2 solution only. You need:
2 x ball bearnings 625, or similar with 5mm inside, 16mm outside
2 x washers with 5mm diameter hole
1 x M5 Screw with nut, at least 30mm length
1 x GT2 Pulley, 20 Teeth and 5mm inside diameter
2 x M5 Screws with nuts 10mm for mounting on frame For assembling see pictures below. Note to put the motor down for about 5-7 mm by rasping long holes in the aluminum angle! ATTENTION: Keep in mind, that the intersection of the new GT2-X belt is very close to the T5-Y belt! You need to adjust both correctly so they do not touch.

comments.text: Printed well & works a treat - Thanks

Did you realize how much dust takes your filament?? And all that dust goes straight inside your nozzle??  
This is a simple case to hold a sponge band.  
Just get a scrub sponge, like 3M Scotch-Brite, cut off a 55mm x 20mm piece, remove the abrasive layer, fold it and insert into the case.  
Then just make it grab your filament and say goodbye to clogged nozzles by dust!!!

Just print as you wish, no special requirements..
If the part become loose on bed before print ends, use some brim.
